<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The aggregate market value of the voting stock held by non-affiliates of the registrant based on the last sale price for such stock at July 30, 2005 (the last business day of the registrant&#146;s most recently completed second fiscal quarter) was approximately $202,371,172 (assuming solely for the purposes of this calculation that all Directors and executive officers of the registrant are &#147;affiliates&#148;).</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Evansville, Indiana</b></font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Annual Report to Securities and Exchange Commission<br> January 28, 2006</font></p>
<p  align="center"><a name="ss_021"></a>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>PART I</b></font></p>
<p><a name="ss_001"></a>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>BUSINESS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Forward-Looking Statements</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">This Annual Report contains forward-looking statements, within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, that involve a number of risks and uncertainties.&#160; A number of factors could cause our actual results, performance, achievements or industry results to be materially different from any future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by these forward-looking statements.&#160; These factors include, but are not limited to: general economic conditions in the areas of the United States in which our stores are located; changes in the overall retail environment and more specifically in the apparel and footwear retail sectors; the potential impact of national and international security concerns on the retail environment; changes in our relationships with key suppliers; the impact of competition and pricing; changes in weather patterns, consumer buying trends and our ability to identify and respond to emerging fashion
trends; the impact of hurricanes or other natural disasters on our stores, as well as on consumer confidence and purchasing in general; risks associated with the seasonality of the retail industry; the availability of desirable store locations at acceptable lease terms and our ability to open new stores in a timely and profitable manner; higher than anticipated costs associated with the closing of underperforming stores; the inability of manufacturers to deliver products in a timely manner; changes in the political and economic environments in the People&#146;s Republic of China, a major manufacturer of footwear; and the continued favorable trade relations between the United States and China and other countries which are the major manufacturers of footwear.&#160; See ITEM 1A.&#160; RISK FACTORS.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>General&#160; </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Shoe Carnival, Inc. is one of the nation&#146;s largest family footwear retailers.&#160; We offer customers a broad assortment of moderately priced dress, casual and athletic footwear for men, women and children with emphasis on national and regional name brands.&#160; We differentiate ourselves from our competitors by our distinctive, highly promotional in-store marketing effort and large stores that average 11,500 square feet, generate an average of approximately $2.5&nbsp;million in annual sales and house an average inventory of approximately 30,000 pairs of shoes per location.&#160; As of January 28, 2006, we operated 263 stores in 23 states in the Midwest, South and Southeast regions of the United States.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We make available free of charge through the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.shoecarnival.com our annual reports on Form 10-K, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, our current reports on Form 8-K and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) or Section 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, as soon as reasonably practicable after we electronically file such material with, or furnish it to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission is available without charge to shareholders, investment professionals and securities analysts upon written request.&#160; Requests should be directed to Investor Relations at the corporate address.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are an Indiana corporation that was initially formed in Delaware in 1993 and reincorporated in Indiana in 1996. </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Business Strategy</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our goal is to continue to grow our net sales and earnings by strengthening our position as the logical destination store for our customers&#146; footwear needs.&#160; Key elements of our business strategy are as follows.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We offer a distinctive shopping experience.</i></b>&#160; Our stores combine competitive pricing with a highly promotional, in-store marketing effort that encourages customer participation and creates a fun and exciting shopping experience.&#160; We promote a high-energy retail environment by decorating with bright lights and bold colors, and by featuring a stage and barker as the focal point in each store.&#160; With a microphone, this barker, or &#147;mic-person&#148;, advertises current specials, organizes contests and games, and assists and educates customers with the features and location of merchandise.&#160; Our mic-person offers limited-duration promotions throughout the day, encouraging the customers to take immediate advantage of our value pricing.&#160; We believe this highly promotional atmosphere results in various competitive advantages, including increased multiple unit sales; the building of a loyal, repeat customer base; the creation of
word-of-mouth advertising; and enhanced sell through of in-season goods.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We offer a broad merchandise assortment. </i></b>&#160;Our objective is to be the destination store-of-choice for a wide range of consumers seeking moderately priced, current season name brand and private label footwear.&#160; Our product assortment includes dress and casual shoes, sandals, boots and a wide assortment of athletic shoes for the entire family.&#160; The average store carries approximately 30,000 pairs of shoes in four general categories&nbsp;-&nbsp;men&#146;s, women&#146;s, children&#146;s and athletics.&#160; In addition to footwear, our stores carry selected accessory items complementary to the sale of footwear.&#160; We place significant emphasis on visual merchandising and the promotion of nationally recognized name brands.&#160; We communicate the importance of these brands through creative signage and other visual aids on the fixtures throughout the stores.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We believe that by offering a wide selection of both athletic and non-athletic footwear, we are able to reduce our exposure to shifts in fashion preferences between those categories.&#160; Our ability to identify and react to fashion changes is a key factor in our sales and earnings performance.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We offer value to our customers.</i></b>&#160; Our marketing effort targets middle income, value conscious consumers seeking name brand footwear for all age groups. &#160;We believe that by offering a wide selection of popular styles of name brand merchandise at competitive prices, we generate broad customer appeal.&#160; Additionally, the time conscious customer appreciates the convenience of one stop shopping for the entire family.&#160; We also believe our highly promotional in-store shopping environment contributes to a reputation of value pricing throughout the store.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We maintain an efficient store level cost structure.</i></b>&#160; Our cost efficient store operations and real estate strategy enable us to price products competitively and earn attractive store level returns.&#160; Low labor costs are achieved by housing merchandise directly on the selling floor in an open stock format, enabling customers who choose to serve themselves.&#160; This reduces the staffing required to assist customers and reduces store level labor costs as a percentage of sales.&#160; We prefer to locate stores predominantly in strip shopping centers in order to take advantage of lower occupancy costs and maximize our exposure to value oriented shoppers.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We rely heavily on information technology.&#160; </i></b>We have invested significant resources in information technology.&#160; Our proprietary inventory management and point-of-sale systems provide corporate management, buyers and store managers with the timely information necessary to monitor and control all phases of operations.&#160; Our store managers are able to monitor sales and gross profit margins on a real-time basis throughout the day.&#160; Reacting to sales trends, our mic-people use this information to choose from among a number of product promotions supplied by our centralized merchandising staff.&#160; Our data warehouse enables the merchandising staff to analyze sales, margin and inventory levels by store, by day, down to the size of shoe if necessary.&#160; Using this information, our merchandise managers meet regularly with vendors to compare their product sales, gross margins and return on inventory investment against previously
stated objectives.&#160; We believe timely access to key business data has enabled us in the past to drive annual comparable store sales increases, manage our markdown activity and improve inventory turnover.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">3</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Growth Strategy</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Key elements of our growth strategy are as follows:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We will to continue to grow our store base.</i></b>&#160; Aside from comparable store sales increases, the majority of our sales and earnings growth is expected to be generated by the opening of new stores.&#160; In 2006, we expect to open between eight and 10 stores, net of store closings.&#160; These new stores will be located in large and small markets within our existing geographic areas.&#160; Our intention is to fill in certain under-penetrated larger markets with additional stores, thereby increasing the performance of the overall market.&#160; We also intend to enter smaller markets that we can fully penetrate with one or two stores.&#160; We generally can advertise more effectively in these markets, which helps to create immediate brand awareness.&#160; We have adjusted, and will continue to adjust, our annual store growth rate based on our view of internal and external opportunities and challenges.&#160; We intend to accelerate our growth in the
latter half of 2007, subject to the availability of sufficient real estate and the continued health of the retail market.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We typically enter larger markets (populations greater than 400,000) by opening two or more stores at approximately the same time.&#160; In smaller markets that can only support a single store, we generally will seek locations in reasonably close proximity to other existing markets.&#160; This strategy supports more efficient management and advertising, as well as reducing distribution costs.&#160; We believe the advantages of clustering stores in existing markets will lead to cost efficiencies and overall incremental sales gains that should more than offset any adverse effect on sales of existing stores.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>One of our major goals is to improve our operating margins.&#160; </i></b>We are focused on improving our operating margins by increasing our gross margin and leveraging general and administrative expenses against a higher sales base.&#160; A primary opportunity to increase our gross margin is to increase women&#146;s non-athletic sales as a percentage of our total business.&#160; Women&#146;s product has historically achieved the highest gross margin.&#160; To achieve this goal, we have improved the fashion content of our women&#146;s merchandise assortment, particularly in the dress and casual categories.&#160; Secondly, to highlight our women&#146;s merchandise, we introduced a new store design in fiscal 2003 that prominently displays women&#146;s footwear immediately upon entering the store.&#160; At the end of fiscal 2005, approximately 128 of our existing stores had the new design.&#160; In addition to new stores, we will incorporate the new design in
stores as they are remodeled, which normally occurs upon lease renewal.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Merchandising</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our merchandising strategy is designed to provide a large selection of moderately priced footwear for the entire family.&#160; Our stores carry an average of approximately 30,000 pairs of shoes featuring a broad assortment of current-season name brand footwear, supplemented with private label merchandise and select name brand closeouts.&#160; Our stores also carry complementary accessories such as handbags, wallets, shoe care items and socks.&#160; The mix of merchandise and the brands offered in a particular store are based upon the demographics of each market, among other factors.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our mic-person offers limited-duration promotions throughout the day, encouraging customers to take immediate advantage of value pricing.&#160; We emphasize name brand merchandise to customers with creative signage and by prominently displaying selected brands on end caps, focal walls and within the aisles.&#160; These displays may highlight a product offering of a single vendor or may make a seasonal or lifestyle statement by highlighting similar footwear from multiple vendors.&#160; These visual merchandising techniques make it easier for customers to shop and focus attention on key name brands.&#160; Expenses for signage and visual displays highlighting a particular brand typically will be partially or fully reimbursed by the vendor.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">4</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

  <p  align=right>

<BR>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top">
  <hr size="1"  align="Left" width="25%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;Children&#146;s includes children&#146;s   athletic shoes.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;Includes men&#146;s and women&#146;s sizes   only.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Women&#146;s, men&#146;s and children&#146;s non-athletic footwear categories are further divided into dress, casual, sport, sandals and boots.&#160; Athletic shoes are classified by functionality, such as running, basketball or fitness shoes.&#160; In fiscal 2005, athletic styles, including children&#146;s sizes, represented slightly more than half of our footwear sales.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Pricing</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our pricing strategy is designed to emphasize value.&#160; By combining current season name brand product with promotional pricing, we feel that we create a better value for customers.&#160; Initial pricing decisions are guided by gross profit margin targets, which vary by merchandise category and depend on whether the item is name brand or private label merchandise.&#160; Markdowns are centrally managed by the buying staff and communicated to the stores through information systems as needed.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In-store signage is used extensively to highlight sales promotions and to advertise promotional pricing to meet or beat competitors&#146; sale prices.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Advertising and Promotion</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In-store promotions are a key element in our marketing effort.&#160; By utilizing both planned and impromptu contests and games, store managers create an environment that encourages customer interaction with store personnel.&#160; For example, with a spin of the Spin-N-Win&#153; Wheel, a customer is enticed to purchase a second pair of shoes by winning an on-the-spot discount.&#160; Promotions of this type exemplify our emphasis on fun and excitement in order to enhance our customers&#146; total shopping experience.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We use various forms of media advertising to communicate the exceptional values offered on specific shoes or entire product categories.&#160; Approximately 55% of our total advertising budget was directed to television and radio in fiscal 2005.&#160; Print media (including newspaper ads, inserts and direct mail) and outdoor advertising accounted for the balance of the budget.&#160; A special effort is made to utilize the cooperative advertising dollars offered by vendors whenever possible.&#160; Major promotions during grand openings and peak selling periods allow customers to win prizes such as gift cards, merchandise or cash.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We strive to make each store opening a major retail event.&#160; Grand openings feature contests and giveaways of cash and prizes.&#160; We believe our grand openings help to establish the high-energy, promotional atmosphere that develops a loyal, repeat customer base and generates word-of-mouth advertising.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">5</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">237</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>




<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At January 28, 2006, we had 263 stores located in 23 states, primarily in the Midwest, South and Southeast regions of the United States.&#160; Although two stores are located in enclosed malls, we prefer strip shopping center locations where occupancy costs are typically lower and we enjoy greater operating freedom to implement our non-traditional retail methods.&#160; We feel that our target customers enjoy the convenience offered by strip shopping centers as opposed to enclosed malls.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All of our stores are leased rather than owned.&#160; We believe the flexibility afforded by leasing allows us to avoid the inherent risks of owning real estate, particularly with respect to under-performing stores.&#160; Before entering a new market, we perform a market, demographic and competition analysis to evaluate the suitability of the potential market.&#160; Potential store site selection criteria include, among other factors, market demographics, traffic counts, the tenant mix of a potential strip shopping center, visibility within the center and from major thoroughfares, overall retail activity of the area and proposed lease terms.&#160; The time required to open a store after signing a lease depends primarily upon the landlord&#146;s ability to deliver the premises.&#160; After we accept the premises from the landlord, we can generally open a store within 45 days.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Critical to the success of opening new stores in larger markets or geographic areas is our ability to cluster stores.&#160; Clustering involves the operation of multiple locations in a particular metropolitan area or in several smaller markets located in reasonable proximity to one another.&#160; The clustering of stores creates cost efficiencies by enabling us to leverage store expenses with respect to advertising, distribution and management costs.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of January 28, 2006, our stores averaged approximately 11,500 square feet, ranging in size from 6,400 to 26,500 square feet.&#160; Our current store prototype utilizes between 6,500 and 12,000 square feet, depending upon, among other factors, the location of the store and the population base the store is expected to service.&#160; The sales area of most stores is approximately 85% of the gross store size.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our stores are designed and fixtured to reflect the high energy level of our retail concept.&#160; Stores are typically equipped with a sound system, microphone and entertainment devices such as the Spin-N-Win&#153; Wheel.&#160; With an open stock format, merchandise is displayed by category, with athletic footwear providing transition between men&#146;s and women&#146;s footwear.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Updated Store Design</i></b>.&#160; The store design and logo utilized by 51% of our stores was introduced in 1996.&#160; This design conveys a carnival-like atmosphere through the use of distinctive signs, flashing colored lights, large mirrors and bold colors.&#160; While we believe the existing design will continue to be successful into the future, a new store design was developed and rolled out in all stores opened and remodeled in fiscal 2003 and after.&#160; The new design incorporates the excitement and energy that makes Shoe Carnival distinctive, but features a contemporary look and feel by utilizing a more muted color scheme, larger-than-life sized graphics, better visual displays and an improved wayfinding system.&#160; In addition, the Shoe Carnival logo was redesigned to reflect the store&#146;s new color scheme and contemporary look.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The new design highlights our women&#146;s non-athletic merchandise by relocating it from an interior position to the front window line.&#160; We also showcase our latest women&#146;s styles on displays, which can be seen by customers as they enter the store.&#160; Prominently displaying the women&#146;s merchandise is one way in which we expect to achieve our goal of raising the percentage of sales of women&#146;s merchandise from 25% in fiscal 2005 to between 28% and 30% over the next four years.&#160; At the end of fiscal 2005, approximately 128 of our stores had the new design.&#160; As designs change, we will continue to remodel stores and open new stores with the latest store concept.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">6</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Store Operations</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Management of store operations is the responsibility of our Executive Vice President - Store Operations, who is assisted by the Senior Vice President - Store Operations, divisional managers, regional managers and the individual store general managers.&#160; There are three divisions designated as the North, Central and South Divisions.&#160; Each divisional manager is responsible for up to approximately twelve regions.&#160; Each regional manager is responsible for the operation of between six and 17 stores and is required to visit each store periodically, concentrating more heavily on under-performing stores.&#160; Regional managers meet with their respective divisional manager and other members of senior management on a periodic basis to discuss strategies, merchandise, advertising, financial performance and personnel requirements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Each store has a general manager and up to three assistant managers, depending on sales volume.&#160; General managers and most assistant managers are paid a salary, while all other store employees are paid on an hourly basis.&#160; We provide an incentive compensation plan for divisional, regional and general managers based primarily upon the attainment of sales, expense control and profitability goals.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Administrative functions are centrally controlled from the corporate headquarters.&#160; These functions include accounting, purchasing, store maintenance, information systems, advertising, human resources, distribution and pricing.&#160; Regional and general managers are expected and encouraged to provide feedback to all corporate departments to improve efficiencies.&#160; Regional and general managers are charged with making certain merchandising decisions necessary to maximize sales and profits primarily through merchandise placement, signage and timely clearance of slower selling items.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Distribution</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We operate a single 200,000 square foot distribution facility in Evansville, Indiana.&#160; The distribution center processes virtually all merchandise prior to shipping it to the stores.&#160; At a minimum, this includes count verification, price and bar code labeling of each unit (when not performed by the manufacturer), redistribution of an order into size assortments and allocation of shipments to individual stores.&#160; Throughout packing, allocating, storing and shipping, our distribution process is essentially paperless.&#160; Merchandise is typically shipped to each store one time per week.&#160; The majority of shipments are handled by a dedicated carrier, with occasional use of common carriers.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In fiscal 2004, we completed a forward-looking logistics study evaluating the need for additional distribution center capacity as we grow.&#160; We intend to replace our existing 200,000 square foot distribution center with a new 410,000 square foot facility.&#160; Construction of the facility began in the spring of 2006.&#160; We anticipate this facility will support the processing and distribution needs of approximately 465 stores.&#160; We will lease the land, building and improvements for an initial period of 15 years.&#160; We have the right to extend the initial lease term for up to three additional, successive, five-year periods.&#160; We will also have the right to expand into a designated expansion area as long as we provide 120 days written notice to the property owner.&#160; Expansion under this option would provide us the processing capacity to support a total of approximately 650 stores.&#160; The new distribution center, located in the Evansville,
Indiana area, will utilize state-of-the-art processing and product movement equipment.&#160; The preliminary cost estimate for the equipment is approximately $18 million.&#160; We expect the new facility to be in operation in January 2007.&#160; See PART II, ITEM 7 &#150;&#160; &#147;2006 Outlook&#148; for further details.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Buying Operations</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Maintaining fresh, fashionable merchandise is critical to our success.&#160; Our buyers stay in touch with evolving trends by shopping fashion-leading markets, attending national trade shows, gathering vendor input and monitoring the current styles shown in leading fashion and lifestyle magazines.&#160; Management of the purchasing function is the responsibility of our Executive Vice President - General Merchandise Manager.&#160; Regional managers are expected to provide input to our merchandising staff regarding market specific fashion trends.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We purchase merchandise from over 170 footwear vendors.&#160; In fiscal 2005, three suppliers, Nike USA, Inc., Adidas Sales, Inc., and Skechers USA, Inc. each accounted for 10%, or more, of our net sales and together accounted for over 36% of our net sales.&#160; Amounts for Adidas Sales, Inc. include our purchases from Reebok International Ltd. for the entire fiscal year.&#160; A loss of any of our key suppliers in certain product categories could have a material adverse effect on our business.&#160; As is common in the industry, we do not have any long-term contracts with suppliers.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">7</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Information Systems</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have devoted significant resources to expand our sophisticated information technology systems.&#160; Our network connects our corporate office to every store, providing up-to-date sales and inventory information as required.&#160; Each store has an independent point-of-sale controller, with two to 12 point-of-sale terminals per store.&#160; To provide maximum flexibility and maintain data integrity, our information systems are based upon relational database technology.&#160; Our distribution facility utilizes a radio frequency network to assure accurate, real-time information throughout the distribution operation.&#160; Each member of the buying and distribution staff has on-line access to up-to-date sales and inventory information broken down by store, style, color, size and width.&#160; Additional data analysis can be quickly provided on demand by the merchandising or data warehouse applications.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A state-of-the-art point-of-sales system uses bar code technology to capture sales, gross margin and inventory information.&#160; The system provides, in addition to other features, full price management (including price look-up), promotion tracking capabilities (in support of the spontaneous nature of the in-store price promotions), real-time sales and gross margin analysis by product category at the store level and customer tracking.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Competition</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The retail footwear business is highly competitive.&#160; We believe the principal competitive factors in our industry are merchandise selection, price, fashion, quality, location, store environment and service.&#160; We compete primarily with department stores, shoe stores, sporting goods stores and mass merchandisers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We compete with most department stores and traditional shoe stores by offering lower prices.&#160; We compete with off-price retailers, mass merchandisers and discount stores by offering a wider and deeper selection of merchandise.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Many of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater financial and other resources.&#160; However, we believe that our distinctive retail format, in combination with our wide merchandise selection, competitive prices and low operating costs, have in the past enabled us to compete effectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Employees</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At January 28, 2006, we had approximately 4,000 employees, of which approximately 2,200 were employed on a part-time or seasonal basis.&#160; The number of employees fluctuates during the year primarily due to seasonality.&#160; None of our employees are represented by a labor union.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We attribute a large portion of our success in various areas of cost control to our inclusion of virtually all management level employees in incentive compensation plans.&#160; We contribute all or a portion of the cost of medical, disability and life insurance coverage for those employees who are eligible to participate in company-sponsored plans.&#160; Additionally, we sponsor a 401(k) retirement plan that is open to all employees who have met the minimum age and workhour requirements.&#160; All employees are eligible to receive discounts on purchases from our stores.&#160; We consider our relationship with our employees to be satisfactory.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Trademarks</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We own the following federally registered trademarks and servicemarks:&nbsp;&nbsp;Shoe Carnival<sup>&#174;</sup>, The Carnival<sup>&#174;</sup>, Donna Lawrence<sup>&#174;</sup>, Oak Meadow<sup>&#174;</sup>, Victoria Spenser<sup>&#174;</sup>, Via Nova<sup>&#174;</sup>, Fresh Stuff<sup>&#174;</sup>, Innocence<sup>&#174;</sup>, Trade Dress<sup>&#174;</sup>, Carnival Lites<sup>&#174; </sup>and Color Block Design<sup>&#174;</sup>.&#160; We believe these marks are valuable and, accordingly, we intend to maintain the marks and the related registrations.&#160; We are not aware of any pending claims of infringement or other challenges to our right to use these marks.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">8</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_002"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 1A</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RISK   FACTORS</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You should carefully consider the following risk factors and all other information contained in this annual report before making an investment decision with respect to our common stock.&#160; Investing in our common stock involves a high degree of risk.&#160; If any of the following risks actually occur, we may not be able to conduct our business as currently planned and our financial condition and operating results could be seriously harmed.&#160; See ITEM 1.&#160; BUSINESS - &#147;Forward-Looking Statements.&#148;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We may not be able to successfully execute our growth strategy, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.</i></b>&#160; We intend to open new stores as a part of our growth strategy.&#160; We may not be able to open all of the new stores contemplated by our growth strategy and the new stores that we open may not be as profitable as existing stores.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The complexity of our operations and management responsibilities will increase as we grow.&#160; Our growth strategy requires that we continue to expand and improve our operating and financial systems and to expand, train and manage our employee base.&#160; In addition, as we open new stores, we may be unable to hire a sufficient number of qualified store personnel or successfully integrate the new stores into our business.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The success of our growth strategy will depend on a number of other factors, many of which are out of our control, including, among other things:</font></p>

 </tr>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the impact of new stores on sales or profitability   of existing stores in the same market.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Due to the risks involved, we may be unable to open new stores at the rates expected.&#160; If we fail to successfully implement our growth strategy, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We may not be able to achieve comparable store sales gains in the future, which could cause a decline in the trading price of our common stock.</i></b>&#160; A variety of factors affect our comparable store sales results, including:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>

  <p>

 </tr>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>

  <p>

  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the results of our merchandising strategies;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the impact of relatively new stores and new markets;   and</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the success of our marketing and promotional   programs.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Declines or fluctuations in our comparable store sales could cause the trading price of our common stock to decline.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We depend on our key suppliers for merchandise and advertising support and the loss of key suppliers could adversely affect our business.</i></b>&#160; Our business depends upon our ability to purchase fashionable, name brand and other merchandise at competitive prices from our suppliers.&#160; In fiscal 2005, three branded suppliers, Nike USA, Inc., </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">9</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Adidas Sales, Inc., including Reebok International Ltd., and Skechers USA, Inc. collectively accounted for over 36% of our net sales.&#160; Name brand suppliers also provide us with cooperative advertising and visual merchandising funds.&#160; A loss of any of our key suppliers in certain product categories could have a material adverse effect on our business.&#160; Although our relations with key suppliers are currently satisfactory and we have adequate sources of name brand and other merchandise at competitive prices, we cannot assure you that we will be able to acquire such merchandise at comparable prices or on comparable terms in the future.&#160; As is common in the industry, we do not have any long-term contracts with our suppliers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>An increase in the cost or a disruption in the flow of our imported goods may decrease our sales and profits.</i></b>&#160; We rely on imported goods to sell in our stores.&#160; Substantially all of the footwear product we sell is manufactured overseas, including the merchandise we import directly from overseas manufacturers and agents and the merchandise we purchase from domestic vendors.&#160; The primary footwear manufacturers are located in China, Brazil and East Asia.&#160; A disruption in the flow of imported merchandise or an increase in the cost of those goods may decrease our sales and profits.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">If imported merchandise becomes more expensive or unavailable, the transition to alternative sources may not occur in time to meet our demands.&#160; Products from alternative sources may be of lesser quality and more expensive than those we currently import.&#160; Other risks associated with our use of imported goods include: disruptions in the flow of imported goods because of factors such as electricity or raw material shortages, work stoppages, strikes and political unrest; problems with oceanic shipping, including shipping container shortages; economic crises and international disputes; increases in the cost of purchasing or shipping foreign merchandise resulting from the failure to maintain normal trade relations with source countries; import duties, import quotas and other trade sanctions; and increases in shipping rates imposed by the trans-Pacific shipping cartel.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Our failure to identify fashion trends could result in lower sales, higher markdowns and lower gross profits.</i></b>&#160; Our success depends upon our ability to anticipate and react to the fashion tastes of our customers and provide merchandise that satisfies customer demand.&#160; Our failure to anticipate, identify or react appropriately to changes in consumer fashion preferences may result in lower sales, higher markdowns to reduce excess inventories and lower gross profits.&#160; Conversely, if we fail to anticipate or react to consumer demand for our products, we may experience inventory shortages, which would result in lost sales and could negatively impact our customer goodwill, our brand image and our profitability.&#160; Moreover, our business relies on continuous changes in fashion preferences.&#160; Stagnating consumer preferences could also result in lower sales and would require us to take higher markdowns to reduce excess
inventories.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Our failure to retain our existing senior management team and to continue to attract qualified personnel could adversely affect our business.</i></b>&#160; Our success depends to a large extent on the continued service of our executive management team.&#160; Departures by executive officers could have a negative impact on our business, as we may not be able to find suitable management personnel to replace departing executives on a timely basis.&#160; Furthermore, our strategy requires us to continue to train, motivate and manage our employees and to attract, motivate and retain additional qualified managerial and merchandising personnel.&#160; Competition for these types of personnel is intense, and we cannot assure you that we will be successful in attracting, assimilating and retaining the personnel required to grow and operate our business profitably.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We face significant competition in our markets and we may be unable to compete favorably.</i></b>&#160; The retail footwear industry is highly competitive.&#160; We compete primarily with department stores, shoe stores, sporting goods stores and mass merchandisers.&#160; Many of our competitors are significantly larger and have substantially greater financial and other resources than we do.&#160; Economic pressures on or bankruptcies of our competition could result in increased pricing pressures.&#160; This competition could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition in the future. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We will require significant funds to implement our growth strategy and meet our other liquidity needs.</i></b>&#160; We cannot assure you that we will be able to generate sufficient cash flow from operations or obtain sufficient borrowings under our existing credit agreement to finance our growth strategy and meet our other liquidity needs.&#160; In 2006, capital expenditures, including assets acquired through leasing arrangements but net of lease incentives, are expected to range from $29&nbsp;million to $31&nbsp;million.&#160; Our actual costs may be greater than anticipated.&#160; We also require working capital to support inventory for our existing stores.&#160; Failure to generate or raise sufficient funds may require us to modify, delay or abandon some of our future growth or expenditure plans.&#160; In addition, our results would be adversely affected if interest rates materially increase from present levels.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">10</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Declines in general economic conditions and fluctuations in consumer confidence and spending could lead to reduced consumer demand for our products.</i></b>&#160; General economic conditions and consumer confidence and spending can decline as a result of numerous factors outside of our control such as rising oil prices, terrorist attacks, acts of war and natural disasters.&#160; While the precise effects of these events on our industry and business are difficult to determine, they could lead to reduced consumer demand for our products and it is possible that they may have an adverse effect on our operating and financial performance.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We would be adversely affected if our distribution or information technology operations were disrupted.</i></b>&#160; We currently operate a single, 200,000 square foot distribution center in Evansville, Indiana.&#160; We intend to replace this distribution center with a 410,000 square foot distribution center in January 2007.&#160; Virtually all merchandise received by our stores, with the exception of a small amount of goods shipped directly to the stores, is and will be shipped through our distribution center.&#160; Our corporate computer network is essential to our distribution process.&#160; If our distribution center is shut down for any reason, such as a national disaster, power outage or terrorist attack, or if our information technology systems do not operate effectively, or if we are the target of attacks or breaches, we could incur significantly higher costs and longer lead times associated with distributing our products to our stores.&#160;
Our insurance only covers costs relating to specified, limited matters such as a shutdown due to fire and windstorms, but does not cover other events such as national disasters or terrorist attacks.&#160; Even in the event of a shutdown due to covered matters, we cannot assure you that our insurance will be sufficient, or that the insurance proceeds will be paid to us in a timely fashion.&#160; Shutdowns or information technology disruptions could have an adverse effect on our operating and financial performance.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Failure to maintain effective internal control over financial reporting could result in a loss of investor confidence in our financial reports and have a material adverse effect on our stock price.</i></b>&#160; We must continue to document, test and evaluate our internal control over financial reporting in order to satisfy the requirements of Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which requires annual reports by management regarding the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting and a report by our independent registered public accounting firm attesting to management&#146;s assessment and the effectiveness of the internal control.&#160; We have expended, and expect that we will continue to expend, significant management time and resources documenting and testing our internal control over financial reporting.&#160; While management&#146;s evaluation as of January 28, 2006 resulted in the conclusion that our internal control
over financial reporting was effective as of that date, we cannot predict the outcome of testing in future periods.&#160; If we conclude in future periods that our internal control over financial reporting is not effective, it could result in lost investor confidence in the accuracy, reliability and completeness of our financial reports.&#160; Any such events could have a material adverse effect on our stock price. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>We are controlled by our principal shareholder.</i></b>&#160; J. Wayne Weaver, our Chairman of the Board of Directors and principal shareholder, his spouse and his adult children together own approximately 43% of our outstanding common stock.&#160; Accordingly, Mr.&nbsp;Weaver is able to exert substantial influence over our management and operations.&#160; In addition, his interests may differ from or be opposed to the interests of our other shareholders, and his control may have the effect of delaying or preventing a change in control that may be favored by other shareholders.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Our stock price may be volatile and could decline substantially.</i></b>&#160; The stock market has, from time to time, experienced extreme price and volume fluctuations.&#160; Many factors may cause the market price for our common stock to decline, including: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>

  <p>

 </tr>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the other risk factors cited in this annual report.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the past, companies that have experienced volatility in the market price of their stock have been the subject of securities class action litigation.&#160; If we become involved in a securities class action litigation in the future, it could result in substantial costs and diversion of management attention and resources, thus harming our business.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">11</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Our quarterly operating results will fluctuate due to seasonality and other factors.</i></b>&#160; Our quarterly results of operations have fluctuated in the past and can be expected to continue to fluctuate in the future.&#160; Our quarterly results of operations are affected by a variety of factors, including:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

  <p>

  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">changes in general economic conditions and consumer   spending patterns; and</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">actions of competitors or co-tenants.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have three distinct peak selling periods: Easter, back-to-school and Christmas.&#160; To prepare for our peak shopping seasons, we must order and keep in stock significantly more merchandise than we would carry during other parts of the year.&#160; Any unanticipated decrease in demand for our products during these peak shopping seasons could require us to sell excess inventory at a substantial markdown, which could reduce our net sales and gross margins and negatively impact our profitability.&#160; Our operating results depend significantly upon the sales generated during these periods.&#160; If our future quarterly results fail to meet the expectations of research analysts, then the market price of our common stock could decline substantially.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Provisions of our organizational documents and Indiana law might deter acquisition bids for us.</i></b>&#160; Our Restated Articles of Incorporation and Indiana corporate laws contain provisions that may discourage other persons from attempting to acquire control of us, including, without limitation, a Board of Directors that has staggered terms for its members, supermajority voting provisions, restrictions on the ability of shareholders to call a special meeting of shareholders and procedural requirements in connection with shareholder proposals or director nominations.&#160; The Board of Directors has the authority to issue preferred stock in one or more series without the approval of the holders of the common stock.&#160; Further, Indiana corporate law contains business combination provisions that, in general, prohibit for five years any business combination with a beneficial owner of more than 10% or more of our common stock unless the holder&#146;s
acquisition of the stock was approved in advance by our Board of Directors.&#160; Indiana corporate law also contains control share acquisition provisions that limit the ability of certain shareholders to vote their shares unless their control share acquisition is approved.&#160; In certain circumstances, the fact that corporate devices are in place that inhibit or discourage takeover attempts could reduce the market value of the common stock.</font></p>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_003"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 1B.</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>UNRESOLVED   STAFF COMMENTS</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">None.</font></p>
<p><a name="ss_004"></a>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>PROPERTIES</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We lease all existing stores and intend to lease all future stores.&#160; All leases for existing stores provide for fixed minimum rentals and most provide for contingent rental payments based upon various specified percentages of sales above minimum levels.&#160; Certain leases also contain escalation clauses for increases in minimum rentals, operating costs and taxes.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">12</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>

  <p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Total Stores</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">263</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of January 28, 2006, we owned our combined corporate headquarters and distribution center, which is located at 8233 Baumgart Road, Evansville, Indiana.&#160; During February 2006, we completed the sale of this facility.&#160; Under the terms of the sale agreement, we will lease our current headquarters and distribution center during the anticipated construction period of both of our new headquarters and distribution center.&#160; The initial term of the lease runs through January 31, 2007 with an option to extend the term by twelve months for one or both of the portions of the combined facility.&#160; The lease additionally provides for early termination to coincide with occupancy of our new facilities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">For additional information with respect to our properties, see ITEM 1. BUSINESS &#150; &#147;Store Location and Design&#148; and &#147;Distribution&#148; as well as PART II, ITEM 7 &#150; &#147;2006 Outlook&#148;.</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_005"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 3.</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>LEGAL   PROCEEDINGS</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are involved in various legal proceedings incidental to the conduct of our business.&#160; While the outcome of any legal proceeding is always uncertain, we do not currently expect that any such proceedings will have a material adverse effect on our financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

<p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Executive Officers</b> <br><br></font></p>

  <td width="5%" valign="top">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">J. Wayne Weaver</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">51</font></p>  </td>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Timothy T. Baker</font></p>  </td>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">49</font></p>  </td>

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Executive Vice President - Store Operations</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">W. Kerry Jackson</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">44</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Executive Vice President - Chief Financial Officer   and Treasurer</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Clifton E. Sifford</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">52</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Executive Vice President - General Merchandise   Manager</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Mr. Weaver</i> is Shoe Carnival&#146;s largest shareholder and has served as Chairman of the Board since March 1988.&#160; From 1978 until February 2, 1993, Mr. Weaver had served as president and chief executive officer of Nine West Group Inc., a designer, developer and marketer of women&#146;s footwear.&#160; He has over 40 years of experience in the footwear industry.&#160; Mr. Weaver is a former director of Nine West Group, Inc.&#160; Mr. Weaver serves as chairman and chief executive officer of Jacksonville Jaguars, LTD and chairman and chief executive officer of LC Footwear, LLC.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Mr. Lemond</i> has been employed as President and Chief Executive Officer since September 1996.&#160; From March 1988 to September 1996, Mr. Lemond served as Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Assistant Secretary.&#160; On February 3, 1994, Mr. Lemond was promoted to the position of Chief Operating Officer.&#160; Mr. Lemond has served as a Director since March 1988.&#160; Prior to March 1988, he served in similar officer capacities with Russell&#146;s&#160; Shoe Biz, Inc.&#160; Prior to joining Russell&#146;s Shoe Biz, Inc. in 1987, Mr. Lemond was a partner with a public accounting firm.&#160; He is a Certified Public Accountant.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Mr. Baker</i> has been employed as Executive Vice President - Store Operations since June 2001.&#160; From March 1994 to June 2001, Mr. Baker served as Senior Vice President - Store Operations.&#160; From May 1992 to March 1994, Mr. Baker served as Vice President - Store Operations.&#160; Prior to that time, he served as one of our regional managers.&#160; From 1983 to June 1989, Mr. Baker held various retail management positions with Payless ShoeSource.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Mr. Jackson</i> has been employed as Executive Vice President - Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer since August 2004.&#160; From June 2001 to August 2004, Mr. Jackson served as Senior Vice President &#150; Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer.&#160; From September 1996 to June 2001, Mr. Jackson served as Vice President &#150; Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer.&#160; From January 1993 to September 1996, Mr. Jackson served as Vice President - Controller and Chief Accounting Officer.&#160; Prior to January 1993, Mr. Jackson held various accounting positions with us.&#160; Prior to joining us in 1988, Mr. Jackson was associated with a public accounting firm.&#160; He is a Certified Public Accountant. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Mr. Sifford</i> has been employed as Executive Vice President - General Merchandise Manager since June 2001.&#160; From April 13, 1997 to June 2001, Mr. Sifford served as Senior Vice President - General Merchandise Manager.&#160; Prior to joining us, Mr. Sifford served as merchandise manager-shoes for Belk Store Services, Inc.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our executive officers serve at the discretion of the Board of Directors.&#160; There is no family relationship between any of the Directors or executive officers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(Pursuant to General Instruction G (3) of Form 10-K, the foregoing information is included as an unnumbered Item in PART I of this Annual Report in lieu of being included in our Proxy Statement for our 2006 Annual Meeting of Shareholders.)</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">14</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>PART II</b></font></p>

<BR>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of March 24, 2006, there were approximately 217 holders of record of our Common Stock and approximately 2,229 beneficial owners of our Common Stock. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We do not currently intend to pay cash dividends on our Common Stock in the foreseeable future.&#160; The payment of any future dividends will be at the discretion of our Board of Directors and will depend upon, among other things, future earnings, operations, capital requirements, our general financial condition and general business conditions.&#160; In addition, our credit agreement contains certain limitations on the payment of dividends.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">No unregistered equity securities were sold by us during fiscal 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We did not purchase any of our equity securities during fiscal 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The information required by this Item concerning securities authorized for issuance under our equity plans has been set forth in or incorporated by reference into PART III, ITEM 12 of this report.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">15</font></p>

  <td  colspan="2" valign="top">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(1)</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="94%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our fiscal year is a 52/53 week year ending on the   Saturday closest to January 31.&#160;   Unless otherwise stated, references to years 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002,   and 2001 relate respectively to the fiscal years ended January 28, 2006,   January 29, 2005, January 31, 2004, February 1, 2003, and February 2, 2002.   Each of those fiscal years consisted of 52 weeks.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Comparable store sales for the periods indicated   include stores that have been open for 13 full months prior to the beginning   of the period, including those stores that have been relocated or   remodeled.&#160; Therefore, stores opened   or closed during the periods indicated are not included in comparable store   sales.</font></p>  </td>

<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">16</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_009"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 7.</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>MANAGEMENT&#146;S   DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following discussion of our financial condition and results of operations should be read together with our consolidated financial statements and notes to those statements included in PART II, ITEM 8 of this Form 10-K.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Overview</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Shoe Carnival, Inc. is one of the nation&#146;s largest family footwear retailers.&#160; As of January 28, 2006, we operated 263 stores in 23 states in the Midwest, South and Southeast regions of the United States.&#160; We offer a distinctive shopping experience, a broad merchandise assortment and value to our customers while maintaining an efficient store level cost structure.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our stores combine competitive pricing with a highly promotional, in-store marketing effort that encourages customer participation and creates a fun and exciting shopping experience.&#160; We believe this highly promotional atmosphere results in various competitive advantages, including increased multiple unit sales; the building of a loyal, repeat customer base; the creation of word-of-mouth advertising; and enhanced sell through of in-season goods.&#160; Our objective is to be the destination store-of-choice for a wide range of consumers seeking moderately priced, current season name brand and private label footwear.&#160; Our product assortment includes dress and casual shoes, sandals, boots and a wide assortment of athletic shoes for the entire family.&#160; We believe that by offering a wide selection of both athletic and non-athletic footwear, we are able to reduce our exposure to shifts in fashion preferences between those categories.&#160; Our ability to
identify and react to fashion changes is a key factor in our sales and earnings performance.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our marketing effort targets middle income, value-conscious consumers seeking name brand footwear for all age groups.&#160; We believe that by offering a wide selection of popular styles of name brand merchandise at competitive prices, we generate broad customer appeal.&#160; Our cost-efficient store operations and real estate strategy enable us to price products competitively and earn attractive store level returns.&#160; Low labor costs are achieved by housing merchandise directly on the selling floor in an open-stock format, enabling customers who choose to serve themselves.&#160; This reduces the staffing required to assist customers and reduces store level labor costs as a percentage of sales.&#160; We locate stores predominantly in strip shopping centers in order to take advantage of lower occupancy costs and maximize our exposure to value-oriented shoppers.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our fiscal year consists of a 52/53 week period ending on the Saturday closest to January 31.&#160; Unless otherwise stated, references to the fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003 relate respectively to the fiscal years ended January 28, 2006, January 29, 2005, and January 31, 2004.&#160; Fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003 consisted of 52 weeks.&#160; Fiscal year 2006 will end on February 3, 2007, and will consist of 53 weeks.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Critical Accounting Policies</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">It is necessary for us to include certain judgements in our reported financial results.&#160; These judgements involve estimates that are inherently uncertain and actual results could differ materially from these estimates.&#160; The accounting policies that require the more significant judgements are:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Merchandise Inventories</i> - Merchandise inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method.&#160; In determining market value, we estimate the future sales price of items of merchandise contained in the inventory as of the balance sheet date.&#160; Factors considered in this determination include, among others, current and recently recorded sales prices, the length of time product has been held in inventory and quantities of various product styles contained in inventory.&#160; The ultimate amount realized from the sale of certain product could differ materially from our estimates.&#160; We also estimate a shrinkage reserve for the period between the last physical count and the balance sheet date.&#160; The estimate for the shrinkage reserve can be affected by changes in merchandise mix and changes in actual shrinkage trends.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Valuation of Long-Lived Assets</i> - We review long-lived assets whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying value of an asset may not be recoverable and annually when no such event has occurred.&#160; We evaluate the ongoing value of assets associated with retail stores that have been open longer than one year.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">17</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">When events such as these occur, the assets subject to impairment are adjusted to estimated fair value and, if applicable, an impairment loss is recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses.&#160; Our assumptions and estimates used in the evaluation of impairment, including current and future economic trends for stores, are subject to a high degree of judgement and if actual results or market conditions differ from those anticipated, additional losses may be recorded.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Deferred Income Taxes</i> - We calculate income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes&#148;, which requires the use of the asset and liability method.&#160; Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on the difference between the consolidated financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis.&#160; Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the tax rates in effect in the years when those temporary differences are expected to reverse.&#160; Inherent in the measurement of these deferred balances are certain judgements and interpretations of existing tax law and other published guidance as applied to our operations.&#160; We anticipate that future taxable income, and prior year taxable income during loss carryback periods, will not be sufficient to recover the full amount of deferred tax
assets.&#160; Therefore, a valuation allowance has been provided for certain state operating losses recorded as a deferred tax asset.&#160; Our effective tax rate considers our judgement of expected tax liabilities in the various taxing jurisdictions within which we are subject to tax.&#160; We have also been involved in tax audits.&#160; At any given time, multiple tax years are subject to audit by various taxing authorities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2006 Outlook</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We plan to make several infrastructure enhancements in fiscal 2006 to enable us to pursue more aggressive expansion opportunities in fiscal 2007 and beyond.&#160; In fiscal 2006, we intend to open between 13 and 15 new stores and close five stores.&#160; We will continue to back fill underpenetrated markets and open smaller, one or two store markets in relatively close proximity to existing markets.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>New Support Facilities</i> - In fiscal 2006, construction has begun on a new distribution center and will begin on a new corporate headquarters as our future store expansion plan requires additional distribution capacity.&#160; Our current corporate headquarters and distribution center are located in a combined facility on a lot of approximately 11 acres.&#160; In mid February 2006, we signed a 15 year lease with a real estate developer who will construct, to our specifications, a new distribution center of approximately 410,000 square feet located on a 43-acre lot in the Evansville, Indiana area.&#160; This location has ready access to I-64, a major east-west interstate, and also has the potential for rail utilization.&#160; We plan to invest approximately $18 million in capital expenditures to equip this facility.&#160; We selected tilt-tray technology to replace our current pack-by-light system for the handling and packaging of shoes into store specific
assortments as directed by our merchandisers.&#160; This technology will allow us to process product through the distribution center at a higher rate.&#160; Once operational, the distribution center is anticipated to support the needs of approximately 465 stores.&#160; The lease provides for the option of expanding the facility to accommodate the processing needs of approximately 650 stores.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We also plan to occupy a new corporate headquarters in the Evansville, Indiana area by the end of the first half of fiscal 2007.&#160; It is our intention to lease this new facility.&#160; We currently utilize approximately 48,000 square feet for our administrative offices.&#160; In order to allow for necessary expansion, our new headquarters will be approximately 60,000 square feet.&#160; We plan to invest approximately $1 million in capital expenditures on furniture and fixtures for this facility.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In February 2006, we sold our current combined distribution center and corporate headquarters and entered into a lease to continue occupancy until such time as our new facilities are available.&#160; The initial lease term expires on January 31, 2007; however the lease has an option that allows us to continue our occupancy until January 31, 2008, if necessary.&#160; It also provides for early termination upon our relocation to new facilities. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><i>Information Technology</i> - In 2006, we will be implementing a wide area network, providing connectivity between our headquarters, distribution center and our stores.&#160; This technology will provide the platform for immediate operational enhancements in the areas of credit and debit exchange fees and provide the infrastructure necessary to further evolve the communication between our many support departments and the operational side of our business. </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">18</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the late spring of 2006, we will also begin utilizing markdown optimization software.&#160; We expect to significantly enhance our gross profit margin potential with this software and its consequential operating changes.&#160; We intend to also use this software as a platform to implement a regional pricing strategy.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Results of Operations</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following table sets forth our results of operations expressed as a percentage of net sales for the following fiscal years:</font></p>

  <p>
