  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">28.4</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>

</table>

<br clear="all">
<BR>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005 Compared to 2004</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net Sales</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the regular course of business, we offer our customers sales incentives including coupons, discounts, and free merchandise.&#160; Sales are recorded net of such incentives and returns and allowances.&#160; If an incentive involves free merchandise, that merchandise is recorded as a zero sale and the cost is included in cost of sales.&#160; Comparable store sales for the periods indicated include stores that have been open for 13 full months prior to the beginning of the period, including those stores that have been relocated or remodeled.&#160; Therefore, stores opened or closed during the periods indicated are not included in comparable store sales.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net sales increased $65.4 million to $655.6 million in fiscal 2005, an 11.1% increase over net sales of $590.2 million in fiscal 2004.&#160; Of the increase, $27.8 million was attributable to the sales generated by the 15 stores opened in fiscal 2005, the effect of a full year&#146;s worth of sales for the 22 stores opened in fiscal 2004, and partially offset by seven store closings.&#160; The balance of the increase was attributable to a comparable store sales increase of 6.9%.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the last half of fiscal 2004, we undertook two initiatives.&#160; The first was to enhance the fashion content of our men&#146;s and women&#146;s non-athletic product and the second was to improve the way in which we advertise to our customers.&#160; In fiscal 2005, our focus on these initiatives led us to the best year, from a sales and earnings perspective, in our history.&#160; The record 6.9% comparable store sales gain for fiscal 2005 was due to the results achieved in both our women&#146;s and men&#146;s non-athletic business.&#160; Our men&#146;s non-athletic product had a comparable store sales increase of 11.0%.&#160; Our women&#146;s non-athletic product had an even greater comparable store sales increase of 14.7%.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As we look forward to fiscal 2006, the focus will remain on increasing our brand recognition, as well as improving the fashion aspect of our business to drive comparable store sales gains through a combination of increased unit sales and growth in average price points.&#160; </font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">19</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Gross Profit</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our gross profit increased $22.5 million to $189.7 million in fiscal 2005, a 13.4% increase from a gross profit of $167.2 million in fiscal 2004.&#160; Our gross profit margin, as a percentage of sales, rose to 28.9% for fiscal 2005 as compared to 28.3% for fiscal 2004.&#160; As a percentage of sales, the merchandise margin increased 0.2% and buying, distribution and occupancy costs decreased 0.4%.&#160; The decrease in buying, distribution and occupancy costs, as a percentage of sales, was due primarily to leveraging occupancy costs against a higher sales base.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Selling, General and Administrative Expenses</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $12.5 million to $158.9 million in fiscal 2005 from $146.4 million in fiscal 2004.&#160; Approximately $5.3 million of this increase was directly attributable to operating the 37 new stores opened in fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2005 (net of seven store closings in fiscal 2005).&#160; We also incurred an increase of $1.9 million in health care costs and an increase of $2.2 million for incentive compensation in fiscal 2005 as compared to fiscal 2004.&#160; The increase in incentive compensation was primarily a result of higher operating earnings, which is the major component of our performance-based incentive plans.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During fiscal 2005, we incurred $1.5 million in store closing costs related to seven fiscal 2005 store closings and impairment charges for three stores expected to be closed in fiscal 2006.&#160; In fiscal 2004, we incurred $565,000 in store closing costs for six stores that were closed in fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2005.&#160; The year-over-year increase is primarily attributable to impairment charges for three stores we expect to close in fiscal 2006.&#160; Barring any additional closings, we anticipate that our remaining fiscal 2006 store closing costs will be less than $145,000.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The aggregate of pre-opening expenses for the 15 new stores in fiscal 2005 was approximately $753,000, or 0.1% of sales, and was $1.7 million, or 0.3% of sales, for the 22 new stores in fiscal 2004.&#160; Our average pre-opening costs per store dropped by nearly 35% in fiscal 2005 to $50,000 from $77,000 in fiscal 2004.&#160; Approximately 65% of this decrease was due to an increase in cooperative advertising dollars received from our vendors and differences in advertising costs in markets where we have opened new stores.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a percentage of sales, selling, general and administrative expenses decreased to 24.2% in fiscal 2005 from the prior year at 24.8%.&#160; This percentage decrease was primarily due to leveraging expenses against a larger sales base.&#160; However, this leveraging was partially offset by a 0.2% increase in employee healthcare and a 0.3% increase in incentive compensation, both as a percentage of sales.&#160; The increase in incentive compensation as a percentage of sales was primarily a result of higher operating earnings, which is the major component of our performance-based incentive plans currently in place.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest Expense-net</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest expense decreased to $354,000 (net of interest income of $171,000) in fiscal 2005 from $658,000 (net of interest income of $73,000) in fiscal 2004.&#160; The decrease was attributable to lower average borrowings in addition to an increase in interest income.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Income Taxes</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The effective income tax rate was 38.4% for fiscal 2005 and 38.0% in fiscal 2004.&#160; The effective income tax rate for both years differed from the statutory rate due primarily to state and local income taxes, net of the federal tax benefit.&#160; In fiscal 2006, increases in state income taxes are expected to increase the effective income tax rate to between 38.5% and 39.0%.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004 Compared to 2003</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net Sales</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net sales increased $32.3 million to $590.2 million in fiscal 2004, a 5.8% increase over net sales of $557.9 million in fiscal 2003.&#160; Of the increase, $36.4 million was attributable to the sales generated by the 22 stores opened in fiscal 2004, the effect of a full year&#146;s worth of sales for the 37 stores opened in fiscal 2003, and partially offset by four store closings.&#160; This increase was offset by a comparable store sales decrease of 0.8%.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">20</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">While sales of athletic footwear and accessories in our comparable stores increased slightly for the 2004 fiscal year, our men&#146;s, women&#146;s and children&#146;s non-athletic footwear categories each experienced declines in comparable store sales.&#160; In the first two quarters of fiscal 2004, we saw declines in our comparable store sales, but ended the year with back-to-back quarterly comparable store sales gains.&#160; We believe the improved sales performance in the second half of the year was at least partly due to enhancing the fashion content of our merchandise offering and to improving the way we advertise to our customers. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Gross Profit</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Gross profit increased $9.0 million to $167.2 million in fiscal 2004, a 5.7% increase from gross profit of $158.2 million in fiscal 2003.&#160; Our gross profit margin as a percentage of sales was 28.3% for fiscal 2004 as compared to 28.4% for fiscal 2003.&#160; As a percentage of sales, the merchandise margin increased 0.4% and buying, distribution and occupancy costs increased 0.5%.&#160; The increase in the merchandise margin as a percentage of sales was primarily driven by a decline in the amount of markdowns necessary to liquidate seasonal product.&#160; The increase in buying, distribution and occupancy costs as a percentage of sales was due to a lack of sales leverage on occupancy costs.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Selling, General and Administrative Expenses</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $8.2 million to $146.4 million in fiscal 2004 from $138.2 million in fiscal 2003. We experienced a $9.5 million increase in expense directly attributable to the operation of the 59 stores opened in fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2003, net of store closings.&#160; This increase was partially offset by a decrease of approximately $1.0 million in health care costs as compared to fiscal 2003.&#160; During fiscal 2004, we incurred $565,000 in asset retirement costs on store closings, relocations and remodels as compared to $789,000 in fiscal 2003.&#160; The aggregate of pre-opening expenses for the 22 new stores opened in fiscal 2004 was approximately $1.7 million, or 0.3% of sales, as compared to $2.5 million, or 0.4% of sales, for the 37 new stores in fiscal 2003. As a percentage of sales, selling, general and administrative expenses remained unchanged from the prior year at 24.8%.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest Expense-Net</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest expense decreased to $658,000 (net of interest income of $73,000) in fiscal 2004 from $714,000 (net of interest income of $15,000) in fiscal 2003.&#160; The decrease was attributable to lower average borrowings in addition to an increase in interest income.&#160; The weighted average interest rate on total debt was 3.6% in fiscal 2004 and 3.0% in fiscal 2003.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Income Taxes</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The effective income tax rate was 38.0% in both fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2003.&#160; The effective income tax rate for both years differed from the statutory rate due primarily to state and local income taxes, net of the federal tax benefit.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">21</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Liquidity and Capital Resources</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our sources and uses of cash are summarized as follows:</font></p>

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>(000&#146;s)</b></font> <br>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>Fiscal years</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

</table>

<br clear="all">
<BR>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our primary sources of funds are cash flows from operations and borrowings under our revolving credit facility.&#160; For fiscal 2005, net cash provided by operating activities was $33.7 million compared to net cash provided by operating activities of $29.1 million for fiscal 2004.&#160; These amounts reflect the income from operations adjusted for non-cash items and working capital changes. The $4.6 million increase in cash provided by operating activities between the two respective periods related primarily to the increase in net income in addition to the slowed growth in inventory associated with a reduced pace of store openings.&#160;&#160; This increase in cash was partially offset by the timing of the payment of accounts payable, accrued liabilities and income taxes.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Working capital increased to $131.8 million at January 28, 2006 from $115.5 million at January 29, 2005, primarily from a $15.4 million increase in cash and cash equivalents.&#160; The current ratio at January 28, 2006 was 2.7 as compared to 2.6 at January 29, 2005.&#160; Long-term debt as a percentage of total capital (long-term debt plus shareholders&#146; equity) was 4.4% at January 29, 2005.&#160; We had no long-term debt at January 28, 2006. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Capital expenditures were $14.7 million in fiscal 2005, $14.2 million in fiscal 2004 and $20.5 million in fiscal 2003.&#160; No capital lease obligations were incurred during this three year period.&#160; Of the fiscal 2005 capital expenditures, approximately $4.2 million was incurred for new stores,&#160; $4.0 million for store remodeling and a relocation, and $3.3 million for software and information technology.&#160; The remaining capital expenditures in fiscal 2005 were incurred for in-store graphics and miscellaneous equipment purchases.&#160; Lease incentives received from landlords were $874,000, $719,000 and $3.3 million for fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Capital expenditures are expected to be $29 million to $31 million in fiscal 2006.&#160; Of this amount, approximately $18 million represents our projected investment in equipment for our new distribution center and approximately $1 million for furniture and fixtures for our new corporate headquarters.&#160; We intend to open 13 to 15 stores at an expected aggregate cost of between $4.0 million and $4.7 million.&#160; The remaining capital expenditures are expected to be incurred for store remodels, visual presentation enhancements and various other store improvements, along with continued investments in technology and normal asset replacement activities.&#160; The actual amount of cash required for capital expenditures for store operations depends in part on the number of new stores opened, the amount of lease incentives, if any, received from landlords and the number of stores remodeled.&#160; The opening of new stores will be dependent upon, among other things,
the availability of desirable locations, the negotiation of acceptable lease terms and general economic and business conditions affecting consumer spending in areas we target for expansion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our current store prototype uses between 6,500 and 12,000 square feet depending upon, among other factors, the location of the store and the population base the store is expected to service.&#160; Capital expenditures for a new store in fiscal 2006 are expected to average approximately $310,000.&#160; The average inventory investment in a new store is expected to range from $425,000 to $750,000 depending on the size and sales expectation of the store and the timing of the new store opening.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">22</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pre-opening expenses, such as advertising, salaries and supplies, are expected to average approximately $55,000 per store in fiscal 2006 as compared to $50,000 in fiscal 2005.&#160; On a per-store basis, for the 15 stores opened during fiscal 2005, the initial inventory investment averaged $533,000, capital expenditures averaged $362,000 and lease incentives received from landlords averaged $45,000.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We anticipate that our existing cash and cash flow from operations, supplemented by borrowings under our revolving credit line, will be sufficient to fund our planned store expansion, the capital investment required for both the new distribution facility and corporate headquarters and other operating cash requirements for at least the next 12 months.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Significant contractual obligations as of January 28, 2006 and the periods in which payments are due include:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>(000&#146;s)</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="13"  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>Payments   Due By Period</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <td  valign="bottom">

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our unsecured credit facility provides for
up to $70 million in cash advances on a revolving basis and commercial letters
of credit.&#160; Borrowings under the revolving credit line are based on
eligible inventory.&#160; The agreement governing the credit facility stipulates
a minimum threshold for net worth, a maximum ratio of funded debt plus rent to
EBITDA plus rent, and a maximum of total distributions for stock repurchases and
cash dividends.&#160; We were in compliance with these requirements as of
January 28, 2006.&#160; Should a default condition be reported, the lenders may
preclude additional borrowings and call all loans and accrued interest at their
discretion.&#160; The credit agreement and amendments thereto are filed as
exhibits to (or incorporated by reference in) this Annual Report on Form
10-K.&#160; There were no borrowings outstanding under the credit facility and
letters of credit outstanding were $8.7 million at January 28, 2006.&#160;
Estimated interest payments on our line of credit are not included in the above
table as our line of credit is subject to frequent borrowing and/or repayment
activities which does not lend itself to reliable forecasting for disclosure
purposes.&#160; As of January 28, 2006, $61.3 million was available to us for
additional borrowings under the credit facility.&#160; On March 31, 2006, the
credit agreement was amended to extend the maturity date to April 30,
2008.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During fiscal 2005, we completed negotiations to assign two of our store operating leases, from stores closed in fiscal 2005, to a third party.&#160; The assignments legally obligate the assignee to assume all obligations under the leases.&#160; As assignor, we remain secondarily liable on the leases during the base terms which end on January 31, 2010&#160; and 2011, respectively.&#160; In our secondary position, we believe it is unlikely that we would be required to cure any event of default.&#160; The minimum future lease payments assumed by the assignee approximated $1.8 million at January 28, 2006 and such amounts are not included in the above table of our contractual obligations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Operating lease payments related to our existing headquarters and distribution center as well as our new distribution facility were not included in the above table of our contractual obligations as these leases were executed subsequent to January 28, 2006.&#160; Had the new distribution facility lease been executed prior to the 2005 fiscal year end, the operating lease payments identified in the above table would have increased in total by $20.9 million, with $225,000 represented in the &#147;Less Than 1 Year&#148; classification, $2.7 million in each of the &#147;1-3 Years&#148; and &#147;4-5 Years&#148; classifications and approximately $15.3 million in the &#147;After 5 Years&#148; classification.&#160; Likewise, the short-term lease on our existing headquarters and distribution center would represent approximately $880,000 in operating lease payments for fiscal 2006.&#160; A lease has not yet been entered into for our new corporate headquarters.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">See Notes 5 and 6 to our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements contained in PART II, ITEM 8 for a discussion of long-term debt and leases, respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">23</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Except for operating leases entered into in the normal course of business, we have not entered into any off-balance sheet arrangements during fiscal 2005 or fiscal 2004, nor did we have any off-balance sheet arrangements outstanding at January 28, 2006 or January 29, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Seasonality</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our quarterly results of operations have fluctuated, and are expected to continue to fluctuate in the future, primarily as a result of seasonal variances and the timing of sales and costs associated with opening new stores.&#160; Non-capital expenditures, such as advertising and payroll, incurred prior to the opening of a new store are charged to expense as incurred.&#160; Therefore, our results of operations may be adversely affected in any quarter in which we incur pre-opening expenses related to the opening of new stores.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have three distinct peak selling periods: Easter, back-to-school and Christmas.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>New Accounting Pronouncements</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Recent accounting pronouncements applicable to our operations are contained in Note 2 - Summary of Significant Accounting Policies contained in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in PART II, ITEM 8 of this report.</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_010"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 7A.</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="91%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>QUANTITATIVE   AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are exposed to market risk in that the interest payable on our credit facility is based on variable interest rates and therefore is affected by changes in market rates.&#160; We do not use interest rate derivative instruments to manage exposure to changes in market interest rates.&#160; A 1% change in the weighted average interest rate charged under the credit facility would have resulted in interest expense fluctuating by approximately $72,000 in fiscal 2005 and $207,000 in fiscal 2004.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">24</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<a name="ss_011"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 8.</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>FINANCIAL   STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.&#160; Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company&#146;s principal executive and principal financial officers and effected by the company&#146;s board of directors, management and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and includes those policies and procedures that:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pertain to the maintenance of records that in   reasonable detail accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and   dispositions of the assets of the company;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Provide reasonable assurance that transactions are   recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in   accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts   and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with   authorizations of management and directors of the company; and</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or   timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the   company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial   statements.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Because of inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.&#160; Projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risks that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of January 28, 2006.&#160; In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations (&#147;COSO&#148;) of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control-Integrated Framework.&#160; Based on our assessment, management believes that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January 28, 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Shoe Carnival, Inc.&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm, Deloitte &amp; Touche LLP, has issued an attestation report dated April 7, 2006 on management&#146;s assessment of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting, and on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting, which is set forth on page 26 of this report.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">25</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Board of Directors and Shareholders<br> Shoe Carnival, Inc., Evansville, Indiana</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have audited management&#146;s assessment, included in the accompanying Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting, that Shoe Carnival, Inc. and subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;) maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of January&nbsp;28, 2006, based on criteria established in <i>Internal Control-Integrated Framework</i> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.&#160; The Company&#146;s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting.&#160; Our responsibility is to express an opinion on management&#146;s assessment and an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).&#160; Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.&#160; Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, evaluating management&#146;s assessment, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.&#160; We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinions.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company&#146;s principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, and effected by the company&#146;s board of directors, management, and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.&#160; A company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting
principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Because of the inherent limitations of internal control over financial reporting, including the possibility of collusion or improper management override of controls, material misstatements due to error or fraud may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.&#160; Also, projections of any evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal control over financial reporting to future periods are subject to the risk that the controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In our opinion, management&#146;s assessment that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 28, 2006, is fairly stated, in all material respects, based on the criteria established in <i>Internal Control-Integrated Framework</i> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.&#160; Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January&nbsp;28, 2006, based on the criteria established in <i>Internal Control-Integrated Framework</i> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule as of and for the year ended January&nbsp;28, 2006 of the Company and our report dated April 7, 2006 expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements and financial statement schedule.</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">26</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Board of Directors and Shareholders<br> Shoe Carnival, Inc.<i><br> </i>Evansville, Indiana</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Shoe Carnival, Inc.&#160; and subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;) as of January 28, 2006 and January 29, 2005, and the related consolidated statements of income, shareholders&#146; equity, and cash flows for the years ended January 28, 2006, January 29, 2005, and January 31, 2004.&#160; Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15.&#160; These financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management.&#160; Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our audits.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).&#160; Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.&#160; An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.&#160; An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.&#160; We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In our opinion, such consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Shoe Carnival, Inc.&#160; and subsidiaries as of January 28, 2006 and January 29, 2005, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the years ended January 28, 2006, January 29, 2005, and January 31, 2004, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.&#160; Also, in our opinion, such financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as of January 28, 2006, based on the criteria established in <i>Internal Control-Integrated Framework</i> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated April 7, 2006 expressed an unqualified opinion on management&#146;s assessment of the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting and an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" color=black face="Times New Roman">See notes to consolidated financial statements.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">30</font></p>

<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">31</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Note 1&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Organization and Description of Business</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Shoe Carnival, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries SCHC, Inc. and Shoe Carnival Ventures, LLC, and SCLC, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of SCHC, Inc. (collectively referred to as &#147;we&#148;, &#147;our&#148; or &#147;us&#148;).&#160; All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.&#160; Our primary activity is the sale of footwear and related products through retail stores operated by us in the Midwest, South and Southeast regions of the United States.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Note 2&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Fiscal Year</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our fiscal year consists of a 52/53 week period ending on the Saturday closest to January 31.&#160; Unless otherwise stated, references to the years 2005, 2004 and 2003 relate respectively to the fiscal years ended January 28, 2006, January 29, 2005 and January 31, 2004.&#160; Fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003 each consisted of 52 weeks.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Cash and Cash Equivalents</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We consider all certificates of deposit and other short-term investments with an original maturity date of three months or less to be cash equivalents. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Merchandise Inventories</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Merchandise inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method. &#160;In determining market value, we estimate the future sales price of items of merchandise contained in the inventory as of the balance sheet date.&#160; Factors considered in this determination include, among others, current and recently recorded sales prices, the length of time product has been held in inventory and quantities of various product styles contained in inventory.&#160; The ultimate amount realized from the sale of certain product could differ materially from our estimates.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Property and Equipment-Net</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Property and equipment is stated at cost.&#160; Depreciation and amortization of property, equipment and leasehold improvements are provided on the straight-line method over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the assets or the applicable lease terms.&#160; Lives used in computing depreciation and amortization range from two to 30 years.&#160; Expenditures for maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred.&#160; Expenditures, which materially increase values, improve capacities or extend useful lives are capitalized.&#160; Upon sale or retirement, the costs and related accumulated depreciation or amortization are eliminated from the respective accounts and any resulting gain or loss is included in operations.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Long-lived assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that full recoverability is questionable.&#160; Factors used in the evaluation include, but are not limited to, our plans for future operations, recent operating results and projected cash flows. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Deferred Lease Incentives</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All cash incentives received from landlords for leasehold improvements and fixturing of stores are recorded as deferred income and amortized over the life of the lease on a straight-line basis as a reduction of rental expense. </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">32</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Accrued Rent</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are party to various lease agreements which require scheduled rent increases over the initial lease term.&#160; Rent expense for such leases is recognized on a straight-line basis over the initial lease term beginning the earlier of the start date of the lease or when we take possession of the property.&#160; The difference between rent based upon scheduled monthly payments and rent expense recognized on a straight-line basis is recorded as accrued rent. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Revenue Recognition</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Revenue from sales of our merchandise is recognized at the time of sale.&#160; In the regular course of business, we offer our customers sales incentives including coupons, discounts, and free merchandise.&#160; Sales are recorded net of such incentives and returns and allowances.&#160; If an incentive involves free merchandise, that merchandise is recorded as a zero sale and the cost is included in cost of sales.&#160; Gift card revenue is recognized at the time of redemption.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Cash Consideration Received From a Vendor</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Cash consideration is primarily received from merchandise vendors.&#160; Cash consideration is either recorded as a reduction of the price paid for the vendor&#146;s products and recorded as a reduction of our cost of sales or if the cash consideration represents a reimbursement of a specific, incremental and identifiable cost then it is recorded as an offset to the same financial statement line item.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Cash consideration received from our vendors includes co-operative advertising/promotion, margin assistance, term discounts, damage allowances and rebates earned for a specific level of purchases over a defined time period.&#160; Cash consideration principally takes the form of credits that we can apply against trade amounts owed.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Cash consideration received after the related merchandise has been sold is recorded as an offset to cost of sales in the period negotiations are finalized.&#160; For cash consideration received on merchandise still in inventory, the allowance is recorded as a reduction to the cost of on-hand inventory and recorded as a reduction of our cost of sales at the time of sale.&#160; Allowances received from vendors representing a reimbursement of specific, incremental and identifiable costs are offset to the same financial statement line item.&#160; Should the allowances received exceed the incremental cost then the excess consideration is recorded as a reduction to the cost of on-hand inventory and allocated to cost of sales in future periods utilizing an average inventory turn rate. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Store Opening Costs</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Non-capital expenditures, such as advertising, payroll and supplies, incurred prior to the opening of a new store are charged to expense in the period they are incurred.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Advertising Costs</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Print, radio and television communication costs are generally expensed when incurred.&#160; Internal production costs are expensed when incurred and external production costs are expensed in the period the advertisement first takes place.&#160; Advertising expenses included in selling, general and administrative expenses were $32.0 million in fiscal 2005, $31.4 million in fiscal 2004 and $28.6 million in fiscal 2003.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have one business segment that offers the same principal product and service throughout the Midwest, South and Southeast regions of the United States.&#160; Based on our current organizational structure, the financial information presented is in compliance with the applicable accounting pronouncement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Income Taxes</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We compute income taxes using the asset and liability method, under which deferred income taxes are provided for the temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and the tax basis of our assets and liabilities.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">33</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Net Income Per Share</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net income per share of common stock is based on the weighted average number of shares and common share equivalents outstanding during the year.&#160; The following table presents a reconciliation of our basic and diluted weighted average common shares outstanding as required by Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No. 128, &#147;Earnings Per Share&#148;:</font></p>

  <p  align="center">

  <p  align="center">

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Dilutive effect of stock options</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">

  <p>

  <p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">231</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">372</font></p>  </td>

</table>
<br clear="all">
<BR>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Options to purchase 3,100, 316,000 and 296,000 shares of common stock in fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, were not included in the computation of diluted shares because the options&#146; exercise prices were greater than the average market price for the period.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Stock-Based Compensation</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In accordance with the provisions of SFAS No. 123, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation&#148;, we have elected to follow the recognition and measurement principles of Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 25 (&#147;APB No. 25&#148;), &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&#148;, and related interpretations.&#160; Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for our stock option and incentive plans other than for awards of restricted shares. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under APB No. 25, because the exercise price of our employee stock options is at least equal to the market price of the underlying stock on the date of the grant, no compensation expense is recognized.&#160; Pro forma information regarding net income and earnings per share is required by SFAS No. 123, and has been determined as if we had accounted for our stock options under the Black-Scholes fair value method described in that statement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At January 28, 2006, 74,500 shares of restricted stock were outstanding.&#160; Of these restricted shares, 72,500 are subject to certain performance criteria and as such qualify as a variable arrangement for accounting purposes under APB No. 25.&#160; Expense is recognized over the applicable vesting period as determined by management&#146;s assessment of the probability of achieving the designated performance criteria.&#160; The remaining 2,000 shares are subject to a one year service period over which the expense is being amortized.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">34</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Had compensation cost for the stock option awards under our stock option and incentive plans been determined based on the grant date fair values, consistent with the method required under SFAS No. 123, our net income and net income per share would have been reduced to the pro forma amounts indicated below:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>New Accounting Pronouncements</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In November 2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (the &#147;FASB&#148;) issued SFAS No. 151, &#147;Inventory Costs, an Amendment of ARB No. 43, Chapter 4&#148;.&#160; SFAS No. 151 amends Accounting Research Bulletin 43, Chapter 4, to clarify that abnormal amounts of idle facility expense, freight, handling costs and wasted materials (spoilage) be recognized as current period charges.&#160; It also requires that allocation of fixed production overheads to the costs of conversion be based on the normal capacity of the production facilities.&#160; SFAS No. 151 is effective for inventory costs incurred during fiscal years beginning after June 15, 2005.&#160; We do not believe the adoption of SFAS No. 151 will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS No. 153, &#147;Exchanges of Nonmonetary Assets, an Amendment of APB Opinion No. 29&#148;.&#160; The guidance in APB Opinion No. 29, &#147;Accounting for Nonmonetary Transactions&#148;, is based on the principle that exchanges of nonmonetary assets should be measured based on the fair value of the assets exchanged.&#160; The guidance in APB Opinion No. 29, however, included certain exceptions to that principle.&#160; SFAS No. 153 amends APB Opinion No. 29 to eliminate the exception for nonmonetary exchanges of similar productive assets and replaces it with a general exception for exchanges of nonmonetary assets that do not have commercial substance.&#160; A nonmonetary exchange has commercial substance if the future cash flows of the entity are expected to</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">35</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">change significantly as a result of the
exchange. SFAS No. 153 is effective for nonmonetary asset exchanges in fiscal
periods beginning after June 15, 2005. We do not believe that the adoption of
SFAS No. 153 will have a material impact on our results of operations or
financial position.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS No. 123 (revised 2004), &#147;Share-Based Payment, (SFAS 123R)&#148;.&#160; SFAS No. 123R addresses the accounting for share-based payments, including grants of stock options.&#160; Under the new standard, companies will no longer be able to account for share-based compensation transactions using the intrinsic method in accordance with APB No. 25.&#160; Historically we have followed APB No. 25 when accounting for stock-based compensation.&#160; Under these rules, the value of certain awards, such as our restricted stock awards, has been included as an expense over the award&#146;s vesting period.&#160; Our stock option awards, however, were granted with exercise prices equal to the grant date share price resulting in no compensation expense under APB No. 25.&#160; With SFAS No. 123R, we will be required to account for such transactions using a fair-value method and recognize the expense in our consolidated statement of
income.&#160; In addition, the new standard amends SFAS No. 95, &#147;Statement
of Cash Flows,&#148; to require that excess tax benefits be reported as a
financing cash flow rather than as a reduction of taxes paid. </font></p>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">SFAS No. 123R was to be effective for
periods beginning after June 15, 2005.&#160; On April 14, 2005, the Securities
and Exchange Commission announced the deferral of the effective date until the
first fiscal year beginning after June 15, 2005.&#160; We will adopt SFAS No.
123R in the first quarter of fiscal 2006 using the modified prospective method,
which requires us to record compensation expense for all awards granted after
the date of adoption, and for the unvested portion of previously granted awards
that remain outstanding at the date of adoption.&#160; Accordingly, prior period
amounts presented in Note 2 will not be restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS
No. 123R.&#160; The pre-tax expense specifically related to the adoption of SFAS
No. 123R is currently estimated at $240,000 for fiscal 2006.&#160; The aggregate
pre-tax stock compensation expense is estimated at $1.5 million when including
the cost for restricted stock awards, which for fiscal 2005 was included as
an expense at its fair value in the results of operations. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In June 2005, the Emerging Issues Task Force (the &#147;EITF&#148;) reached a consensus on EITF Issue No. 05-6, &#147;Determining the Amortization Period for Leasehold Improvements&#148;. &#160;This EITF guidance requires that leasehold improvements acquired in a business combination or purchased subsequent to the inception of a lease be amortized over the lesser of the useful life of the assets or a term that includes renewals that are reasonably assured at the date of the business combination or purchase.&#160; The guidance is effective for periods beginning after June 29, 2005.&#160; The adoption of EITF Issue No. 05-6 has not had a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Use of Management Estimates</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires that we make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements.&#160; The reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period may be affected by the estimates and assumptions we are required to make.&#160; Actual results could differ from those estimates.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Reclassifications</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Certain amounts in the fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2003 consolidated financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the fiscal 2005 presentation.</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>
<br clear="all">
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have an unsecured credit agreement (the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;) with a bank group, which allows for both cash advances and the issuance of letters of credit.&#160;&#160; The maximum&#160; available under the credit&#160; facility is $70 million.&#160; On March 31, 2006, the Credit Agreement was amended to extend the maturity date to April 30, 2008.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Borrowings under the revolving credit line are based on eligible inventory.&#160; The Credit Agreement governing the credit facility stipulates a minimum threshold for net worth, a maximum ratio of funded debt plus rent to EBITDA plus rent, and a maximum of total distributions for stock repurchases and cash dividends.&#160; We were in compliance with these requirements as of January 28, 2006.&#160; Should a default condition be reported, the lenders may preclude additional borrowings and call all loans and accrued interest at their discretion.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The credit facility bears interest, at our option, at the agent bank&#146;s prime rate (7.25% at January 28, 2006) minus 0.5% or LIBOR plus from 0.75% to 1.5%, depending on our achievement of certain performance criteria.&#160; A commitment fee is charged, at our option, at 0.3% per annum on the unused portion of the bank group&#146;s commitment or 0.15% per annum of the total commitment.&#160;&#160; Outstanding letters of credit at the end of fiscal 2005 were approximately $8.7 million.&#160; As of January 28, 2006, $61.3 million was available to us for additional borrowings under the credit facility.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">37</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Note 6&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Leases</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We lease all of our retail locations and certain equipment under operating leases expiring at various dates through fiscal 2016.&#160;&#160; Various of these lease agreements require scheduled rent increases over the initial lease term.&#160; Rent expense for such leases is recognized on a straight-line basis over the initial lease term beginning the earlier of the start date of the lease or when we take possession of the property.&#160; The difference between rent based upon scheduled monthly payments and rent expense recognized on a straight-line basis is recorded as accrued rent.&#160; All cash incentives received from landlords for leasehold improvements and fixturing of stores are recorded as deferred income and amortized over the life of the lease on a straight-line basis as a reduction of rental expense.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Certain leases provide for contingent rents that are not measurable at inception.&#160; These contingent rents are primarily based on a percentage of sales that are in excess of a predetermined level.&#160; These amounts are excluded from minimum rent and are included in the determination of total rent expense when it is probable that the expense has been incurred and the amount is reasonably estimable.&#160; Certain leases also contain escalation clauses for increases in operating costs and taxes. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During fiscal 2005, we completed negotiations to assign two of our store operating leases, from stores closed in fiscal 2005, to a third party.&#160; The assignments legally obligate the assignee to assume all obligations under the leases.&#160; As assignor, we remain secondarily liable on the leases during the base terms which end on January 31, 2010&#160; and 2011, respectively.&#160; In our secondary position, we believe it is unlikely that we would be required to cure any event of default.&#160; The minimum future lease payments assumed by the assignee approximated $1.8 million at January 28, 2006 and such amounts are not included in the below future minimum lease payments.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Subsequent to January 28, 2006, we sold
our combined corporate headquarters and distribution center.&#160; Under the
terms of the sale agreement, we will lease our current headquarters and
distribution center during the anticipated construction period of both our new
headquarters and distribution center.&#160; Also subsequent to January 28, 2006,
we entered into the lease for our new distribution center. Had the new
distribution facility lease been executed prior to the 2005 fiscal year end, the
operating lease payments included in the future minimum lease payment table
would have increased in total by $20.9 million and been spread over 15
years.&#160; Likewise, the short-term lease on our existing headquarters and
distribution center would have represented approximately $880,000 in operating lease
payments for fiscal 2006.&#160; A lease has not yet been entered into for our
new corporate headquarters.</font></p>


<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Rental expense for our operating leases consisted of:</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Investment in equipment under capital lease, which is included in property and equipment, was:</font></p>
<table align="left"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="80%">
  <tr>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>(000&#146;s)</b></font></p></td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom"><p  align="center"> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>January 28,<br>
        2006</b></font></p></td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom"><p  align="center"> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>January 29,<br>
        2005</b></font></p></td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td  valign="bottom"></td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom"><hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
    </td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom"><hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
    </td>
    <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
  </tr>
  <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <td width="74%" valign="bottom"><p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Equipment</font></p></td>
    <td width="2%" valign="bottom"><p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td width="1%" valign="bottom"><p> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p></td>
    <td width="9%" valign="bottom"><p  align=right> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">0</font></p></td>
    <td width="2%" valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
    <td width="1%" valign="bottom"><p> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p></td>

  </tr>

<br>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We realized a tax benefit of $1,222,000 in fiscal 2005, $730,000 in fiscal 2004 and $315,000 in fiscal 2003 as a result of the exercise of stock options, which is recorded in &#145;shareholders&#146; equity.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Tax reserves have been established, which we believe to be adequate in relation to the potential for additional assessments.&#160; Once established, reserves are adjusted only when more information becomes available or when an event occurs necessitating a change to the reserves.&#160; The resolution of tax matters will not have a material effect on our consolidated financial condition, although a resolution could have a material impact on our consolidated statement of income for a particular future period and our effective tax rate.</font></p>
<p>

<br clear="all">
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A valuation allowance has been provided for certain state operating losses recorded as a deferred tax asset.&#160; We anticipate that future taxable income, and prior year taxable income during loss carryback periods, will not be sufficient to recover the full amount of deferred tax assets.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Note 8&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Employee Benefit Plans</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Retirement Savings Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On February 24, 1994, our Board of Directors approved the Shoe Carnival Retirement Savings Plan (the &#147;Retirement Plan&#148;).&#160; The Retirement Plan is open to all employees who have been employed for one year, are at least 21 years of age and who work at least 1,000 hours in a defined year.&#160; The primary savings mechanism under the Retirement Plan is a 401(k) plan under which an employee may contribute up to 20% of earnings with us matching the first 4% at a rate of 50% up until December 31, 2003.&#160; The match was reduced effective January 1, 2004 to the first 2% of contributions at a rate of 50%.&#160; Effective January 1, 2005, the match was restored to 50% of the first 4% of the employee deferral.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Employee and employer contributions are paid to a trustee and invested in up to 16 investment options at the participants&#146; direction.&#160; Our contributions to the participants&#146; accounts become fully vested once they have reached their third anniversary of employment with us.&#160; Contributions charged to expense in fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003 were $427,000, $225,000 and $366,000, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Stock Purchase Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On May 11, 1995, our shareholders approved the Shoe Carnival, Inc. Employee Stock Purchase Plan (the &#147;Stock Purchase Plan&#148;) as adopted by our Board of Directors on February 9, 1995.&#160; The Stock Purchase Plan reserves 300,000 shares of our common stock (subject to adjustment for any subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and certain other changes in the common stock) for issuance and sale to any employee who has been employed for more than a year at the beginning of the calendar year, and who is not a 10% owner of our stock, at 85% of the then fair market value up to a maximum of $5,000 in any calendar year.&#160; Under the plan, 9,200, 13,100 and 12,800 shares of common stock were purchased by participants in the plan and proceeds to us for the sale of those shares were approximately $147,000, $154,000 and $166,000 each for the fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">40</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>


<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Deferred Compensation Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In fiscal 2000, we established a non-qualified deferred compensation plan for certain key employees who, due to Internal Revenue Service guidelines, cannot take full advantage of the employer sponsored 401(k) plan.&#160; Participants in the plan elect on an annual basis to defer, on a pre-tax basis, portions of their current compensation until retirement, or earlier if so elected.&#160; While not required to, we can match a portion of the employees&#146; contributions, which would be subject to vesting requirements.&#160; The compensation deferred under this plan is credited with earnings or losses measured by the mirrored rate of return on investments elected by plan participants.&#160; The plan is currently unfunded.&#160; Compensation expense for our match and earnings on the deferred amounts for fiscal years 2005, 2004 and 2003 were $433,000, $180,000 and $299,000, respectively.&#160; Total deferred compensation liability at January 28, 2006 and January 29,
2005 was $2,263,000 and $1,651,000, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Note 9&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Stock Option and Incentive Plans</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>1993 Stock Option and Incentive Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effective January 15, 1993, our Board of Directors and shareholders approved the 1993 Stock Option and Incentive Plan (the &#147;1993 Plan&#148;).&#160; The 1993 Plan reserved for issuance 1,500,000 shares of our common stock (subject to adjustment for any subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and certain other changes in the common stock) pursuant to any incentive awards granted by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors which administers the 1993 Plan.&#160; The 1993 Plan provided for the grant of incentive awards in the form of stock options or restricted stock awards to officers and other key employees.&#160; Stock options granted under the 1993 Plan may be either options intended to qualify for federal income tax purposes as &#147;incentive stock options&#148; or options not qualifying for favorable tax treatment (&#147;non-qualified stock options&#148;).&#160; On January 14, 2003, the 1993 Plan expired and no further stock option grants will
be made under the plan.&#160; Previously issued stock option grants can be exercised for up to 10 years from the date of grant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Outside Directors Stock Option Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effective March 4, 1999, our Board of Directors approved the Outside Directors Stock Option Plan (the &#147;Directors Plan&#148;).&#160; The Directors Plan reserves for issuance 25,000 shares of our common stock (subject to adjustment for any subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and certain other changes to the common stock).&#160; The Directors Plan calls for each non-employee Director to receive on April 1<sup>st</sup> of each year an option to purchase 1,000 shares of our common stock at the market price on the date of grant.&#160; The options will vest six months from the grant date and expire ten years from the date of grant.&#160; During March 2005, our Board of Directors suspended all further automatic grants of stock options to non-employee Directors under the Directors Plan.&#160; On June 14, 2005, our 2000 Stock Option and Incentive Plan was amended by our Board of Directors and shareholders to allow non-employee Directors to participate.&#160; Each
non-employee Director, on or about January 1 of each year, will receive an annual grant of 500 shares of restricted stock.&#160; The restrictions on the shares will lapse after a one year time period.&#160; At January 28, 2006, 9,000 shares of unissued common stock were reserved for possible future grants under the Directors Plan.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2000 Stock Option and Incentive Plan</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effective June 8, 2000, our Board of Directors and shareholders approved the 2000 Stock Option and Incentive Plan (the &#147;2000 Plan&#148;).&#160; The 2000 Plan reserved for issuance 1,000,000 shares of our common stock (subject to adjustment for any subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and certain other changes in the common stock) pursuant to any incentive awards granted by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors which administers the 2000 Plan.&#160; On June 11, 2004, the 2000 Plan was amended by our Board of Directors and shareholders to increase the number of shares reserved for issuance to 1,500,000 (subject to adjustment for any subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and certain other changes in the common stock).&#160; On June 14, 2005, the 2000 Plan was further amended by our Board of Directors and shareholders to include our non-employee Directors as individuals eligible to receive awards; provided that the exercise price of all
options granted may not be less than the fair market value of our Common Stock on the date that the option is granted; and deleted the provision permitting loans to participants.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">41</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Shoe Carnival, Inc.<br> Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - continued</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The 2000 Plan provides for the grant of incentive awards in the form of stock options or restricted stock awards to directors, officers and other key employees.&#160; Stock options granted under the 2000 Plan may be either options intended to qualify for federal income tax purposes as &#147;incentive stock options&#148; or options not qualifying for favorable tax treatment (&#147;non-qualified stock options&#148;).&#160; At January 28, 2006, 533,260 shares of unissued common stock were reserved for future grants under the plan.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following table summarizes the stock option transactions pursuant to the stock option plans for the three-year period ended January 28, 2006:</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
